awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Inexpensive Automatic Classification And Counting Of Insects To Enable Precision Agriculture
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in improving crop yields while reducing pesticide use. Insects damage or destroy about $150 B of crops each year. Improving the accuracy and timeliness of insect surveillance will allow more effective pest management, allowing the insect interventions to be targeted in space and time; for example, rather than broadly spraying harsh pesticides across an entire field, the proposed system could suggest spraying of a milder (and cheaper) pesticide in select “hot spots” at the optimal time of day. Reducing the volume of pesticides has further positive benefits by reducing pollution and potentially mitigating colony collapse disorder. The hardware, algorithms, representations, and data models created in this project can be applied broadly to mosquito surveillance, with implications for control of insect-vectored diseases of both humans and livestock. 

The proposed project will advance the state-of-the-art in flying insect classification, with the goal of improving insect surveillance for precision agriculture. The study will advance the use of algorithms and representations for a wide range of conditions (temperature, pressure, humidity) encountered in the field, as these conditions affect air density, which in turn impacts insect flight.  Current models use standard models for density and lift, treating insects as idealized aerodynamic objects and ignoring effects of the environment on insect physiology. This project will use machine learning to improve model accuracy and precision.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project created an end-to-end platform for insect surveillance in support of precision agriculture. Novel sensors were created that can be placed in a farmer?s field. Insects are attracted to these sensors (by a combination of chemical lures, lights, colors and other cues), and when they arrive, our sensors extract physiological signals that are then input into novel classification algorithms that can predict the insect?s sex and species with high accuracy. This information is then pushed to the farmers mobile device, so that she can use this information  to allow highly targeted use of pesticides or pheromones to control the insect pests. This is in contrast to the ?blanket spraying? that many farmers must resort to in the absence of insect surveillance.
The system created by this project required novel contributions in computer hardware (sensors, wireless networking, power management),  computer software (machine learning, cloud computing, user interfaces) and entomology (manipulating insect behaviors and interactions with the sensors). We demonstrated intellectual merit in each of these areas. Moreover, the tight integration of computational and entomological knowledge is a further source of unique intellectual merit that has resulted in several pending patents. The system has been successfully field tested in multiple US states, with multiple crops and pests. In addition to our internal tests, there are now peer-reviewed third-party independent tests that demonstrate the utility and practicality of our system.
Our insect surveillance system has the potential to help not only farmers, but society at large.  By reducing crop lost to insect pests, we are improving food security. Moreover, carefully targeted insect control can use significantly less pesticides, and pesticide use has been implicated in climate change and declining bee populations (colony collapse disorder).
Our company is based in the Inland Empire of California, a region that has long been recognized as economically disadvantaged. We have created three full time jobs here, and plan to expand that to at least twelve jobs in the coming year.


Last Modified: 10/27/2022
Modified by: Leslie Hickle
